JUNE WEEK TICKETS WILL DR. ORROK LECTURES ON
POWER DEVELOPMENT
BE SOLD ON PARTIAL
AT ASSEMBLY
PAYMENT BASIS
Ticket Price Reduced. Six Dances Traces Progress of Power Since Time
of James Watt. Illustrates
Included in Program; Biese
Talk with Slides
Will Play at Three

A new method of purchasing
June Week Tickets has been arranged by the Committee; partial
payments will be accepted on the
total price of the tickets.
In a few days cards will be issued by the Committee, and the
students will be given an opportunity to sign these. In so signing, a man pledges himself to pay
$7.00 by May 20, and the balance
of the price of the ticket, $10.00,
by the first of June. In order to
make the second payment easy,
the Treasurer's office has agreed
to attach. the caution money of
any man who wants to pay in
that way,' for the final payment
on the ticket. However, this
method of payment is not at all
obligatory on the part of the purchaser of the ticket.
Two Payments

The cards can be obtained from
any of the executive committee:
Gardner, Klein, Brown, or Parsons. The two payments will be
accepted by any of these men, or
at the Post Office, or Treasurer's
office.
The price of the tickets has
been materially reduced from that
of last year, as the former price
was $20.00 per ticket. The seniors
will only be required to pay
$15.00, and the underclassmen
$17.00. "For the number of attractions that will be offered, this
is an unusually low charge," said
Chairman Gardner, of the June
Week Committee.
Senior Ball at Belvedere

As has been the custom in the
past two years, the Senior Ball
will be held in the -Belvedere Hotel, and the orchestra will be Paul
Biese's Syncopators. A total of
six dances will be held, with
Biese's Orchestra performing at
three of them, and the well-known
Blue Jays, Hopkins' own, tooting
at the rest.

PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 21, 1925

VOL. XXIX, No 48

For everyone except engineering students in the audience at the
assembly last Thursday, the talk
on "Power and Power -Development," by Dr. G. A. Orrok, one of
the leading consulting engineers
of the country, probably held
more interest than information.
Over 70 lantern slides, shown in
rapid succession, presented an
overpowering array of electric
and steam power plants from the
time of James Watt to the present
day, in this country and abroad.
Mentions James Watt

Dr. Orrok began his lecture
with a few words about James
Watt, who invented the first
steam power plant. Before the
time of this genius man had used
little else than his own muscles
for his varied activities. Wind
and water were not harnessed as
extensively and effectively as they
are now. Not until James* Watt,
after years of work and study, put
his steam boiler on the market
did the dormant wheels of the
mighty industries of the world begin to turn, impelled by the giant
Steam. This was in 1780.

TUDOR-STUART CLUB
ELECTS EIGHT MEN
Eight new men were elected to the Tudor-Stuart Club
at their annual Spring elections last Friday.
Those admitted to the luxurious domains of the club
on the third floor of Gilman
Hall were as follows: Don S.
Colt, '26, Ludlow Baldwin,
'26, Gordon M. Stick, '26,
Jesse Slingluff, '26, Charles
H. Dorsey, '27, Henry Jarrett, '27, Karl E. Miller, '25
and Henry Callard,-'27.
The club was founded in
1918 by Sir William and
Lady Osler. It is endowed
with a collection of books belonging originally to Revere
Osler and added to by club
members.

PRESIDENT GIVES BRIEF RESUME OF
PROPOSED NEW PLAN FOR UNIVERSITY
By DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW
In reply to inquiries from many of our Alumni and students I
venture to outline briefly the plan for the reorganization of the University which I have proposed. In as much as the plan contemplates
the withdrawal of the University from its present relations with the
state of Maryland, it cannot be adopted until after conference with
the state authorities. Such a conference is not possible until the
Assembly meets in January, 1927. Consequently no plan affecting
the relations with the state can be put into action till after that date.
Furthermore, provision would have to be made for four years of
courses of instruction similar to those now given for those students
who may wish to enter the University in the fall of 1926. It is thus
seen that the plan proposed can probably come into complete opera-

Gwinn Wins Two

Richard Gwinn led the field to
the tape in the mile and two mile
runs while Ridgely Edwards carried off the honors in the 440 and
880-yard dashes. Gilpin won the
shot put. Conning placed third in
both hurdles while Meredith was
a close second to Edwards in the
quarter. The freshmen, Blades
and Vivell, took second and third
in the high jump.
The Gobblers were especially
strong in the field events, excluding the Blue Jays from a single
place in either the discus or the
javelin throws.

follows, it being understood that many details have not yet been
elaborated:
1. The University would not provide for elementary collegiate
instruction, meaning by "elementary" those.courses ordinarily given
in the first two years of the American college.
2. The University would confine itself to advanced work in
certain special fields, in which it has the necessary staff of professors
and the necessary equipment in the way of laboratories or libraries

courses would be formulated by the professors in charge of each particular subject. It may be said in general that a student who has
graduated from a Junior College or who has completed two years at
a standard college might expect to be admitted.
4. The only degrees to be conferred by the Philosophical Faculty would be Master of Arts, for which three years of residence
would be required ordinarily, and Doctor of Philosophy, for which
an additional year at least would be requisite. In the formal statement of the requirements for these degrees proficiency and achievement rather than years of residence would be emphasized.
5. One concomitant feature of the plan would inevitably be the
ultimate withdrawal of the University from activities in which it is
now engaged, but which are not distinctly connected with advanced
work.
6. Changes would be made in the School of Engineering so that
in effect Engineering would be considered as on the same basis as
Medicine, Hygiene, and subjects such as Physics, Chemistry or
Biology.
7. It is clear that such features of modern collegiate life as "organized athletics," "college activities," etc.. would not assume the
same importance as at present.

DR. ORROK SPEAKS
Continued from page 1

8 horse-power; in England, to*
4.5; in German, to 3.5; in France
and Italy, to 3, and in Russia, to 1.
Whereas in former days, said
Dr. Orrok, the gage of the advance of civilization in various
countries was measured by the
use of soap or of pig-iron, at the
present day, the index of a nation's supremacy is its use of
pow er.
After this introduction to his
subject, Dr. Orrok showed dozens
of lantern slides of dynamos, of
James Watt's invention, of immense water-power plants, of turbines, of gas engines, of high tension switchboards, of mammoth
electric generators, of a great
many power stations in Europe
and America.
Slides of special interest included an aerial photograph of the
gigantic Dalmarrock Station in
Scotland, a picture of an English
high tension switchboard enclosed
in cast iron instead of concrete,
Pictures of the Waterside Station
of New York, and several photos
of the mammoth Wilson Dam at
Niuscle Shoals, with its enormous
turbines and flood crates.
The slides illustrated vividly
the rapid growth and development
of the use of steam and electric
power since 1780.
Dr. Orrok was prevailed upon
to speak at the Hopkins Assembly by Dr. Christie, of the engineering department. The lecturer has just returned to New
York City from a tour in the
South.

Professor Lemaire is the third
French Exchange Professor to
Speak in this vicinity on Engineering topics. He is assistant director of the "Ecole Centrale Lyonnaise" and a Reserve Officer in the
French Navy. He has carried on
research in a number of fields of
engineering, having made experiments in connection with the gycompass, submarine
roscopic
acoustics, war tank equipment,
and the development of a liquid
compass used by the French in
the late war. During the war, he
directed the important radio station at Bordeaux.
The .subjects of the lectures follow: April 21,"The Silk Industry
in Lyons"; April 22, "The School
of Technology, Lyons"; April 23,
"The Design and Proper Adjustment of Automobile Parts"; April
24, "Color Ic'hotography."

.The Alexander K. Barton Cup,
presented to the Trustees of the
University at the Commemoration
Exercises last February, and now
in the hands of Mr. Iddings, the
University treasurer, is shortly to
be set up in the rotunda of the
Johns Hopkins Library, opposite
the librarian's desk.
The cup, which is shown in the
accompanying picture, is to have
engraved upon it each year the
name of the senior who has best
exemplified, during his stay at
Hopkins, Alexander K. Barton's
characteristics of courage, steadfastness, self-denial, self-sacrifice,
and willing service to the University. A small replica of the cup is
to be presented to the winning
senior on Class Day.
The large cup is thirteen inches
high and has a spread of a halt
inch less. The inscription it bears
is as follows:

HY waste time and energy trying to
twist yourself into an engineer when
your natural bent is away from matters
technical? It isn't necessary.
In these days, industry, and particularly
the electrical industry, is so broad as to require men in all lines of work. Engineers
ofcourse, but there is plenty ofopportunity
for men in the purchasing, manufacturing,
accounting, legal and other commercial
departments as well.
There's a good rule to follow. Find out
what work you are naturally fitted for —
then go to it. And isn't it better to be a
first-rate A. B. than a second-rate E. E.?

JUNE WEEK TICKETS WILL DR. ORROK LECTURES ON
POWER DEVELOPMENT
BE SOLD ON PARTIAL
AT ASSEMBLY
PAYMENT BASIS
Ticket Price Reduced. Six Dances Traces Progress of Power Since Time
of James Watt. Illustrates
Included in Program; Biese
Talk with Slides
Will Play at Three

A new method of purchasing
June Week Tickets has been arranged by the Committee; partial
payments will be accepted on the
total price of the tickets.
In a few days cards will be issued by the Committee, and the
students will be given an opportunity to sign these. In so signing, a man pledges himself to pay
$7.00 by May 20, and the balance
of the price of the ticket, $10.00,
by the first of June. In order to
make the second payment easy,
the Treasurer's office has agreed
to attach. the caution money of
any man who wants to pay in
that way,' for the final payment
on the ticket. However, this
method of payment is not at all
obligatory on the part of the purchaser of the ticket.
Two Payments

The cards can be obtained from
any of the executive committee:
Gardner, Klein, Brown, or Parsons. The two payments will be
accepted by any of these men, or
at the Post Office, or Treasurer's
office.
The price of the tickets has
been materially reduced from that
of last year, as the former price
was $20.00 per ticket. The seniors
will only be required to pay
$15.00, and the underclassmen
$17.00. "For the number of attractions that will be offered, this
is an unusually low charge," said
Chairman Gardner, of the June
Week Committee.
Senior Ball at Belvedere

As has been the custom in the
past two years, the Senior Ball
will be held in the -Belvedere Hotel, and the orchestra will be Paul
Biese's Syncopators. A total of
six dances will be held, with
Biese's Orchestra performing at
three of them, and the well-known
Blue Jays, Hopkins' own, tooting
at the rest.

PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 21, 1925

VOL. XXIX, No 48

For everyone except engineering students in the audience at the
assembly last Thursday, the talk
on "Power and Power -Development," by Dr. G. A. Orrok, one of
the leading consulting engineers
of the country, probably held
more interest than information.
Over 70 lantern slides, shown in
rapid succession, presented an
overpowering array of electric
and steam power plants from the
time of James Watt to the present
day, in this country and abroad.
Mentions James Watt

Dr. Orrok began his lecture
with a few words about James
Watt, who invented the first
steam power plant. Before the
time of this genius man had used
little else than his own muscles
for his varied activities. Wind
and water were not harnessed as
extensively and effectively as they
are now. Not until James* Watt,
after years of work and study, put
his steam boiler on the market
did the dormant wheels of the
mighty industries of the world begin to turn, impelled by the giant
Steam. This was in 1780.

TUDOR-STUART CLUB
ELECTS EIGHT MEN
Eight new men were elected to the Tudor-Stuart Club
at their annual Spring elections last Friday.
Those admitted to the luxurious domains of the club
on the third floor of Gilman
Hall were as follows: Don S.
Colt, '26, Ludlow Baldwin,
'26, Gordon M. Stick, '26,
Jesse Slingluff, '26, Charles
H. Dorsey, '27, Henry Jarrett, '27, Karl E. Miller, '25
and Henry Callard,-'27.
The club was founded in
1918 by Sir William and
Lady Osler. It is endowed
with a collection of books belonging originally to Revere
Osler and added to by club
members.

PRESIDENT GIVES BRIEF RESUME OF
PROPOSED NEW PLAN FOR UNIVERSITY
By DR. FRANK J. GOODNOW
In reply to inquiries from many of our Alumni and students I
venture to outline briefly the plan for the reorganization of the University which I have proposed. In as much as the plan contemplates
the withdrawal of the University from its present relations with the
state of Maryland, it cannot be adopted until after conference with
the state authorities. Such a conference is not possible until the
Assembly meets in January, 1927. Consequently no plan affecting
the relations with the state can be put into action till after that date.
Furthermore, provision would have to be made for four years of
courses of instruction similar to those now given for those students
who may wish to enter the University in the fall of 1926. It is thus
seen that the plan proposed can probably come into complete opera-

Gwinn Wins Two

Richard Gwinn led the field to
the tape in the mile and two mile
runs while Ridgely Edwards carried off the honors in the 440 and
880-yard dashes. Gilpin won the
shot put. Conning placed third in
both hurdles while Meredith was
a close second to Edwards in the
quarter. The freshmen, Blades
and Vivell, took second and third
in the high jump.
The Gobblers were especially
strong in the field events, excluding the Blue Jays from a single
place in either the discus or the
javelin throws.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter
FOUNDED 1897

DR. GOODNOW OUTLINES NEW PLAN
Continued from page 1 col. 2

WELL DOCTOR, WE'LL TRY

courses would be formulated by the professors in charge of each particular subject. It may be said in general that a student who has
graduated from a Junior College or who has completed two years at
a standard college might expect to be admitted.
4. The only degrees to be conferred by the Philosophical Faculty would be Master of Arts, for which three years of residence
would be required ordinarily, and Doctor of Philosophy, for which
an additional year at least would be requisite. In the formal statement of the requirements for these degrees proficiency and achievement rather than years of residence would be emphasized.
5. One concomitant feature of the plan would inevitably be the
ultimate withdrawal of the University from activities in which it is
now engaged, but which are not distinctly connected with advanced
work.
6. Changes would be made in the School of Engineering so that
in effect Engineering would be considered as on the same basis as
Medicine, Hygiene, and subjects such as Physics, Chemistry or
Biology.
7. It is clear that such features of modern collegiate life as "organized athletics," "college activities," etc.. would not assume the
same importance as at present.

DR. ORROK SPEAKS
Continued from page 1

8 horse-power; in England, to*

Whereas in former days, said
Dr. Orrok, the gage of the advance of civilization in various
countries was measured by the
use of soap or of pig-iron, at the
present day, the index of a nation's supremacy is its use of
pow er.
After this introduction to his
subject, Dr. Orrok showed dozens
of lantern slides of dynamos, of
James Watt's invention, of immense water-power plants, of turbines, of gas engines, of high tension switchboards, of mammoth
electric generators, of a great
many power stations in Europe
and America.
Slides of special interest included an aerial photograph of the
gigantic Dalmarrock Station in
Scotland, a picture of an English
high tension switchboard enclosed
in cast iron instead of concrete,
Pictures of the Waterside Station
of New York, and several photos
of the mammoth Wilson Dam at
Niuscle Shoals, with its enormous
turbines and flood crates.
The slides illustrated vividly
the rapid growth and development
of the use of steam and electric
power since 1780.
Dr. Orrok was prevailed upon
to speak at the Hopkins Assembly by Dr. Christie, of the engineering department. The lecturer has just returned to New
York City from a tour in the
South.

Professor Lemaire is the third
French Exchange Professor to
Speak in this vicinity on Engineering topics. He is assistant director of the "Ecole Centrale Lyonnaise" and a Reserve Officer in the
French Navy. He has carried on
research in a number of fields of
engineering, having made experiments in connection with the gycompass, submarine
roscopic
acoustics, war tank equipment,
and the development of a liquid
compass used by the French in
the late war. During the war, he
directed the important radio station at Bordeaux.
The .subjects of the lectures follow: April 21,"The Silk Industry
in Lyons"; April 22, "The School
of Technology, Lyons"; April 23,
"The Design and Proper Adjustment of Automobile Parts"; April
24, "Color Ic'hotography."

.The Alexander K. Barton Cup,
presented to the Trustees of the
University at the Commemoration
Exercises last February, and now
in the hands of Mr. Iddings, the
University treasurer, is shortly to
be set up in the rotunda of the
Johns Hopkins Library, opposite
the librarian's desk.
The cup, which is shown in the
accompanying picture, is to have
engraved upon it each year the
name of the senior who has best
exemplified, during his stay at
Hopkins, Alexander K. Barton's
characteristics of courage, steadfastness, self-denial, self-sacrifice,
and willing service to the University. A small replica of the cup is
to be presented to the winning
senior on Class Day.
The large cup is thirteen inches
high and has a spread of a halt
inch less. The inscription it bears
is as follows:

HY waste time and energy trying to
twist yourself into an engineer when
your natural bent is away from matters
technical? It isn't necessary.
In these days, industry, and particularly
the electrical industry, is so broad as to require men in all lines of work. Engineers
ofcourse, but there is plenty ofopportunity
for men in the purchasing, manufacturing,
accounting, legal and other commercial
departments as well.
There's a good rule to follow. Find out
what work you are naturally fitted for —
then go to it. And isn't it better to be a
first-rate A. B. than a second-rate E. E.?
